items.title: cannot import name 'LogDNAHandler'
items.body: Even after installed latest version I am getting this error. Also tried from source, but no luck....

items.title: Unsupported `meta` keyword argument
items.body:
```
ERROR _log() got an unexpected keyword argument 'meta'
Traceback (most recent call last):
  ...
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/logging/__init__.py", line 1383, in info
    self._log(INFO, msg, args, **kwargs)
TypeError: _log() got an unexpected keyword argument 'meta'
```

Under some configuration conditions, logging calls are passed to LoggingAdapter which doesn't accept `meta` as keyword: https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/1ed61617a4a6632905ad6a0b440cd2cafb8b6414/Lib/logging/__init__.py#L1860

What can we do about that?

items.title: set app name
items.body: how can I set the app name for my log events? I would like to query and segment based on app. I've been testing the functionality out in an ipython shell and the app name on the ingestion servers is `ipython-input-##-############`

items.title: [Bug] logDNA does not use the env option
interpolation not working in logging
items.body:
Hi,

I'm following the tutorial and it looks like logging using the string interpolation `%s` doesn't seem to work with this library. Here's my simple code:

```python
import os
import logging
from logdna import LogDNAHandler


logger = logging.getLogger('logdna')
logger.setLevel(logging.INFO)

logdna_handler = LogDNAHandler('MY_API_KEY', {
  'hostname': 'myhostname',
  'max_length': False
})

logger.addHandler(logdna_handler)
logger.info('hello world from %s', 'test')
```

However, in the LogDNA UI, I only see the following: `hello world from %s`
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/644176/51081947-84479780-16ca-11e9-8090-21e5db27ac29.png)

Can you help advise?

Thanks,
Henry

items.title: RecursionError when queue full and LogDNA can't be reached
items.body: If a new log message is emitted while the handler's queue size meets the [hard-coded](https://github.com/logdna/python/blob/master/logdna/logdna.py#L38) [1MB limit](https://github.com/logdna/python/blob/master/logdna/configs.py#L10), it attempts to [flush all messages to LogDNA in the same thread as the logger](https://github.com/logdna/python/blob/master/logdna/logdna.py#L61-L62). If the messages can't successfully be sent to LogDNA's servers (due to connectivity issues, maybe invalid auth, perhaps I forgot to fill the tank with internet juice, possibly aliens — [_probably aliens_](# "definitely aliens")), exceptions cause more log messages — and because the queue couldn't be flushed, it's still over the queue size limit, so the handler attempts to flush immediately in the same thread. Eventually, the number of frames exceeds `sys.getrecursionlimit()` and a `RecursionError` is thrown. Once a connection can be established, the queue can be drained, and it's all quiet on the western front.

items.title: NameError: name 'gethostname' is not defined
items.body:
The function gethostname doesn't exist on python3.6

```
     log_dna = LogDNAHandler('5c0924a736cc432b89a7a961ac9b2bec')
   File "/usr/local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/logdna/logdna.py", line 18, in __init__
     self.hostname = options['hostname'] if 'hostname' in options else gethostname()
 NameError: name 'gethostname' is not defined
```

items.title: gethostname not defined error
items.body:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test.py", line 16, in <module>
    test = LogDNAHandler(key, options)
  File "/home/vinod/work/venv_python3.6/lib/python3.6/site-packages/logdna/logdna.py", line 18, in __init__
    self.hostname = options['hostname'] if 'hostname' in options else gethostname()
NameError: name 'gethostname' is not defined
```
This is because `gethostname` is not imported. Easy fix is to call `socket.gethostname()`.

`self.hostname = options['hostname'] if 'hostname' in options else gethostname()`
should be replaced with
`self.hostname = options['hostname'] if 'hostname' in options else socket.gethostname()`
  
logdna version is 1.2.3

items.title: LogDNAHandler.emit fails with non-keyword arguments
items.body:
Hi. I've tried to add LogDNAHandler to logging configuration of some existing project and noticed that it started raise a lot of exceptions. If the record was logged with non-keyword arguments, like

    logger.debug("User %s is now %s", username, status)

Then logger would fail with `TypeError: tuple indices must be integers or slices, not str`. Still, that's a valid and reasonably common way to use standard library logging.

This happens because:

    opts = {}
    if 'args' in record:
        opts = record['args']
    ...
    if 'level' in opts:
        message['level'] = opts['level']

And `record["args"]` is a list, e.g.:

    {
        "args": ["drdaeman", "active"],
        "message: "User drdaeman is now active",
        "msg": "User %s is now %s",
        "levelname": "DEBUG",
        "levelno": 10,
        ....
    }

I know, the structured logging and keyword arguments are the way to go, but legacy logging code and quick hacks (to print some debug data quick) are reality.

Also, I'm not sure it is a good idea to use `record.args` at all - in standard library's `LogRecord`, its sole purpose is to convert from `msg` to `message`. Maybe this logic should be put behind some `options["use_args"]` flag.

items.title: Documentation errors
items.body:
Noticed a couple of things in the readme:

1. It makes reference to the MAC address/ip address in the 'setup' section but I can't see anywhere this is used in the code

2. The documentation for `LogDNAHandler` says the first option should be `key`, but in the code it's actually `token`

items.title: non-JSON serializable metadata
items.body:
If an object that cannot be JSON serialized is added to the metadata of a log entry, the LogDNA logger can never recover. A TypeError is raised in the `flush` method every time the method is invoked due to this metadata. Either a way to clear the buffer programmatically or (ideally) the library handles this specific exception by removing the offending entry from the buffer and inserting a log message indicating the problem and action performed.

```
  File "/home/ubuntu/app/lib/python3.5/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 1423, in log_exception
    ), exc_info=exc_info)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/logging/__init__.py", line 1308, in error
    self._log(ERROR, msg, args, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/logging/__init__.py", line 1415, in _log
    self.handle(record)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/logging/__init__.py", line 1425, in handle
    self.callHandlers(record)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/logging/__init__.py", line 1487, in callHandlers
    hdlr.handle(record)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/logging/__init__.py", line 855, in handle
    self.emit(record)
  File "/home/ubuntu/app/lib/python3.5/site-packages/logdna/logdna.py", line 113, in emit
    self.bufferLog(message)
  File "/home/ubuntu/app/lib/python3.5/site-packages/logdna/logdna.py", line 51, in bufferLog
    self.flush()
  File "/home/ubuntu/app/lib/python3.5/site-packages/logdna/logdna.py", line 69, in flush
    resp = requests.post(url=defaults['LOGDNA_URL'], json=data, auth=('user', self.token), params={ 'hostname': self.hostname }, stream=True, timeout=defaults['MAX_REQUEST_TIMEOUT'])
  File "/home/ubuntu/app/lib/python3.5/site-packages/requests/api.py", line 111, in post
    return request('post', url, data=data, json=json, **kwargs)
  File "/home/ubuntu/app/lib/python3.5/site-packages/requests/api.py", line 57, in request
    return session.request(method=method, url=url, **kwargs)
  File "/home/ubuntu/app/lib/python3.5/site-packages/requests/sessions.py", line 461, in request
    prep = self.prepare_request(req)
  File "/home/ubuntu/app/lib/python3.5/site-packages/requests/sessions.py", line 394, in prepare_request
    hooks=merge_hooks(request.hooks, self.hooks),
  File "/home/ubuntu/app/lib/python3.5/site-packages/requests/models.py", line 298, in prepare
    self.prepare_body(data, files, json)
  File "/home/ubuntu/app/lib/python3.5/site-packages/requests/models.py", line 424, in prepare_body
    body = complexjson.dumps(json)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/json/__init__.py", line 230, in dumps
    return _default_encoder.encode(obj)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/json/encoder.py", line 198, in encode
    chunks = self.iterencode(o, _one_shot=True)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/json/encoder.py", line 256, in iterencode
    return _iterencode(o, 0)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.5/json/encoder.py", line 179, in default
    raise TypeError(repr(o) + " is not JSON serializable")
TypeError: RecursionError('maximum recursion depth exceeded while calling a Python object',) is not JSON serializable
```

items.title: Commit 9053931 broke python 3 support
items.body: The error message if request fails does not have (). Also this should be logged to a logger for this library otherwise it will put data on the application stdout.

items.title: request post does not timeout
items.body:
There is no timeout parameter being used on the requests post.  If there is a connection issue when flushing the logs the application can lock forever.  I am happy to send a merge request, but I am not quite sure what the ideal solution is here. 

One thought I had was to just defer the flush after a timeout.   If we do that I think the buffer should continue to grow until MAX_BUF_BYTE_LIMIT.  Once this is hit log messages just keep getting dropped.   Another option would be to keep dropping the oldest messages until the buffer is small enough.

Thanks!
